solution.text:
Given points are : P=(_{i}_,_{j}_), Q=(_{i}_,_{{j+l}}_) and R(_{{i+k}}_,_{j}_).
Apply distance formula between P and R :
i.e., Distance = \(\sqrt {(x_1-x_2)^2 + (y_1-y_2)^2}\)
Where, \(x_1 = _{{i+k}}_ , x_2 = _{i}_ , y_1 = _{j}_ , y_2 = _{j}_\)
Substituting the values in distance formula to find the distance between given points.
i.e., Distance = PR = \(\sqrt {(_{{i+k}}_-_{i}_)^2 + (_{j}_-_{j}_)^2}\)
i.e., PR = \(\sqrt {(_{k}_)^2}\)
i.e., PR = \(\sqrt {_{{pow(k,2)}}_}\)
i.e., PR = _{k}_
Now, Distance between P and Q:
i.e., Distance = PQ = \(\sqrt {(_{i}_-_{i}_)^2 + (_{{j+l}}_-_{j}_)^2}\)
i.e., PQ = \(\sqrt {(_{l}_)^2}\)
i.e., PQ = \(\sqrt {_{{pow(l,2)}}_}\)
i.e., PQ = _{l}_
Finally, find the distance between QR:
i.e., Distance = QR = \(\sqrt {(_{{i+k}}_-_{i}_)^2 + (_{j}_-_{{j+l}}_)^2}\)
i.e., QR = \(\sqrt {(_{k}_)^2 + (-_{l}_)^2}\)
i.e., QR = \(\sqrt {_{{pow(k,2)}}_ + _{{pow((l),2)}}_}\)
i.e., QR = \(\sqrt {_{{pow(k,2) + pow((l),2)}}_}\)
i.e., QR = _{m}_
Here, \(PQ^2 + PR^2 = QR^2\)
So, by the converse of Pythagoras theorem, we have \(\angle P = 90^\circ\). Therefore, PQR is a right triangle.
